question: Question_A_02
hints:
The projection \emph{$\text{Proj}_{c}a$} is the projection of $a$ onto
$c$. If you remember the formula for this, you may use it directly. If
you don't remember the formula, check the diagram below with $a$, $c$,
and $\text{Proj}_{c}a$. Use the picture to help you deduce the formula.

Let $\hat{c} = \frac{c}{|c|}$. Using the picture below as a guide for a
sketch of what a projection is

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Projection.jpg}
\caption{Projection.jpg}
\end{figure}

we can draw the following conclusions. In the image and below we assume
that the angle is acute. If the angle is obtuse the final result is the
same, and the argument is very similar.

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $\cos \theta =  \frac{|\text{Proj}_{c}a|}{|a|}$
\item
  $\cos \theta  = \frac{a\cdot c}{|a||c|}$ (by the definition of the dot
  product)
\item
  Thus $\frac{|\text{Proj}_{c}a|}{|a|} = \frac{a\cdot c}{|a||c|}$ and
  solving gives
\end{enumerate}

\[|\text{Proj}_{c}a| = \frac{a\cdot c}{|c|}\]

So now we know the length of the desired projection. The direction is
\emph{c}. To make sure that the length of the vector in the final answer
is the one calculated above, we choose the unit vector $\hat{c}$
instead:

\[\text{Proj}_{c}a = \left( \frac{a\cdot c}{|c|}\right) \hat{c} = \frac{a\cdot c}{|c|^2} c\]
